commit_message:
[LVM] Restore target config during ensure_export

If server crash or reboot happened, LIO target configuration
will be initialized after boot up a server. Currently, Cinder
has a functionality to save LIO target configuration to save
file at several checkpoint.

If LIO target service is configured properly, LIO target
configuration is restored by this service during boot up
a server, but if not, existing in-use volumes would become
inconsistent status after c-vol service starts.

If there is no iSCSI target configuration during
ensure_export, LIO dirver should restore the saved
configuration file to avoid the problem.

Closes-Bug: #1536248
Change-Id: I74d300ba26a08b6f423f5ed3e13495b73cfbbd52
(cherry picked from commit 5cec4056eb061004b400c1dc5b946bf890b4bab0)

Fix is_suse() check for openSUSE distros

We need to do a substring match on the vendor here. As most releases return
"openSUSE project" for the vendor.

commit_message:
Log INFO message when setting admin state up flag to False for OVS port

Disabling admin state can cause confusion in OVS agent logs as to why
VLAN 4095 is set to a particular port. This commit adds an extra INFO
log message when admin state is disabled. There is no log emitted
upon enabling admin state as there is already a detailed log entry
logged in treat_devices_added_or_updated() function.

Change-Id: I1301db8fea75af211f66a1914d1f0b706a6d5b36
Closes-Bug: 1463891
(cherry picked from commit 7ca04daa71910b578303845a363883fa036358f7)

commit_message:
Add clean step in iLO drivers to activate iLO license

Added a manual clean step to iLO management interface for
supporting activation of iLO license.

Closes-Bug: #1526218
Depends-On: I0e34407133684e34c4ab9446b3521a24f3038f92
Co-Authored-By: R-Vaishnavi <itsvaishnavi@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I9af33a9455a5e0d5280e31c9e1f20778ce022437
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/21/259921/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(ilo_management, '_execute_ilo_clean_step', spec_set=True, autospec=True) def test_activate_license(self, clean_step_mock): with task_manager.acquire(self.context, self.node.uuid, shared=False) as task: # ------------------------------------------------------------------- # GIVEN # ------------------------------------------------------------------- activate_license_args = { 'ilo_license_key': 'a_secretive_ilo_license__key'} # ------------------------------------------------------------------- # WHEN # ------------------------------------------------------------------- task.driver.management.activate_license(task, **activate_license_args) # ------------------------------------------------------------------- # THEN # ------------------------------------------------------------------- clean_step_mock.assert_called_once_with( task.node, 'activate_license', 'a_secretive_ilo_license__key') @mock.patch.object(ilo_management, '_execute_ilo_clean_step', spec_set=True, autospec=True) def test_activate_license_throws_error_if_no_license_key_provided( self, clean_step_mock): with task_manager.acquire(self.context, self.node.uuid, shared=False) as task: # ------------------------------------------------------------------- # GIVEN # ------------------------------------------------------------------- activate_license_args = {'ilo_license_key': None} # --------------------------------------------------------------- # WHEN & THEN # --------------------------------------------------------------- self.assertRaises(exception.MissingParameterValue, task.driver.management.activate_license, task, **activate_license_args) self.assertFalse(clean_step_mock.called)

commit_message:
Revert "tests: Collect info on failure of conn_tester"

More info in bug report. I suggest we first revert, then
re-introduce the collect_debug_info patch with a different
approach. I suspect the fix is not trivial if indeed ordering
is an issue and the namespaces are cleaned up before
collect_debug_info is fired.

Related-Bug: #1548547
Change-Id: Ice93abbc6e143cdbb90e7d41d1be86dc9eb05006

commit_message:
Add test cases to test some commands with '--wait' and fix bug

"server image create"
"server rebuild"
"server resize"
Above 3 commands are not covered by unit test.
So add some unit tests.

Meanwhile, fix bug. Now that image name is an optional argument,
we'd better record error messages with positional arguments
instead of optional argument. So, record server name.

Change-Id: I41bc025d4824dc46f63a3213d82e1528bacbbe12

commit_message:
Deprecated revocation functions

Several functions for generating revocation events were written with
the assumption they would be called externally. This is no longer the
planned approach. These events will be re-placed with "liveness" checks
for the resources, and thus the events themselves will not be generated.

Change-Id: I5a229a0b58fb42db13acf7422f0154084b239f4d

commit_message:
Added #nosec to sahara.utils.hacking package

The sahara.utils.hacking package is used for testing, as such the
usages of subprocess within it should be marked as nosec according
to the bandit documentation.

Change-Id: If9299b050b9b158a78ab90b63afd94a5d4cbbf2c
Closes-Bug: #1552468

commit_message:
NetApp: Fix SSH Client File Creation in Unit Test

A bug was introduced where ssh_known_hosts file is created when the unit
tests in test_netapp.py are run. This patch adds mocks to the ssh init
calls to prevent this file creation.

Change-Id: Ie8ac4e7a5236e6735c7c2f4f50c5383f5f23d38e
Closes-bug: #1550542

commit_message:
Support PATCH of queue metadata

This patch adds support to the v1.1 and v2 API for PATCH to update queue
metadata. Depends on server support for PATCH waiting to be merged here
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/280941/

Change-Id: I9dec8ab8b3f99d48b4a42fde6244d38038e4662f
Depends-On: Iba6d7a0ca5cf7a755c20d9af69d5c52687142dff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/73/288073/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif not len(new_meta): # if metadata is empty dict, clear existing metadata else: core.queue_update(trans, req, self._name, metadata=new_meta)

commit_message:
Add sample devstack local.conf

We've been given feedback that the current directions are too
hard to follow. Providing a sample full local.conf would make
it easier.

Change-Id: Iae278e3df14e7fe23bde81dee5c37c4173d2a20e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/58/278558/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1. Download DevStack (git clone) 2. Update local.conf You may follow the customization instructions below or use the example local.conf. 3. Run ``stack.sh`` .. note:: This installs a headless JRE. If you are working on a desktop based OS (such as Ubuntu 14.04), this may cause tools like pycharms to no longer launch. You can switch between JREs and back: to a headed JRE version using: "sudo update-alternatives --config java". Full example local.conf ======================= The example local.conf MAY not be up to date with the rest of devstack. You will need to look through the settings and potentially customize it to your liking, especially ``HOST_IP``. :download:`local.conf <local.conf>` Existing local.conf customization ================================= 1. Add this repo as an external repository::2. Configure desired searchlight pluginsservices. Each integrated service may need to be specifically enabled in devstack and may require additional configuration settings to work with searchlight. For example, typically, you will need to add the3. Customize searchlight configuration Searchlight documentation talks about settings in ``searchlight.conf``. To customize searchlight.conf settingss, add then under the following section in ``local.conf``:: [[post-config|$SEARCHLIGHT_CONF]]
deleted_lines: 1. Download DevStack 2. Add this repo as an external repository::2. Customize searchlight configuration To customize the searchlight configuration, add settings under the following section in ``local.conf``:: [[post-config|$SEARCHLIGHT_CONF]] 3. Add Plugin Configuration Hooksservices. Each integrated service may require additional configuration settings. For example, typically, you will need to add the4. Run ``stack.sh`` .. note:: This installs a headless JRE. If you are working on a desktop based OS (such as Ubuntu 14.04), this may cause tools like pycharms to no longer launch. You can switch between JREs and back: to a headed JRE version using: "sudo update-alternatives --config java".

[cli-ref] Update python-barbicanclient to 4.0.0

Closes-Bug: #1488934

Change-Id: I32d914b145bd69ab2589664f49ddbd148d53bf64
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/93/288193/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This chapter documents :command:`barbican` version ``4.0.0``. usage: barbican [--version] [-v | -q] [--log-file LOG_FILE] [-h] [--debug]``--log-file LOG_FILE`` Specify a file to log output. Disabled by default. ``env[OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION]`` or 3... _barbican_acl_delete: barbican acl delete ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican acl delete [-h] URI Delete ACLs for a secret or container as identified by its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret or container. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit .. _barbican_acl_get: barbican acl get ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican acl get [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] URI Retrieve ACLs for a secret or container by providing its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret or container. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit .. _barbican_acl_submit: barbican acl submit ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican acl submit [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] [--user [USERS]] [--project-access | --no-project-access] [--operation-type {read}] URI Submit ACL on a secret or container as identified by its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret or container. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit ``--user [USERS], -u [USERS]`` Keystone userid(s) for ACL. ``--project-access`` Flag to enable project access behavior. ``--no-project-access`` Flag to disable project access behavior. ``--operation-type {read}, -o {read}`` Type of Barbican operation ACL is set for .. _barbican_acl_user_add: barbican acl user add ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican acl user add [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] [--user [USERS]] [--project-access | --no-project-access] [--operation-type {read}] URI Add ACL users to a secret or container as identified by its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret or container. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit ``--user [USERS], -u [USERS]`` Keystone userid(s) for ACL. ``--project-access`` Flag to enable project access behavior. ``--no-project-access`` Flag to disable project access behavior. ``--operation-type {read}, -o {read}`` Type of Barbican operation ACL is set for .. _barbican_acl_user_remove: barbican acl user remove ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican acl user remove [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] [--user [USERS]] [--project-access | --no-project-access] [--operation-type {read}] URI Remove ACL users from a secret or container as identified by its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret or container. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit ``--user [USERS], -u [USERS]`` Keystone userid(s) for ACL. ``--project-access`` Flag to enable project access behavior. ``--no-project-access`` Flag to disable project access behavior. ``--operation-type {read}, -o {read}`` Type of Barbican operation ACL is set for usage: barbican ca get [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] usage: barbican ca list [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent].. _barbican_secret_container_create: barbican secret container create ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ usage: barbican secret container create [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--prefix PREFIX] [--name NAME] [--type TYPE] [--secret SECRET].. _barbican_secret_container_delete: barbican secret container delete ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ usage: barbican secret container delete [-h] URI.. _barbican_secret_container_get: barbican secret container get ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ usage: barbican secret container get [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--prefix PREFIX] URI.. _barbican_secret_container_list: barbican secret container list ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ usage: barbican secret container list [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] [--limit LIMIT] [--offset OFFSET] [--name NAME] [--type TYPE] usage: barbican secret get [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] usage: barbican secret list [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}].. _barbican_secret_order_create: barbican secret order create ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican secret order create [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--prefix PREFIX] [--name NAME] [--algorithm ALGORITHM] [--bit-length BIT_LENGTH] [--mode MODE] [--payload-content-type PAYLOAD_CONTENT_TYPE] [--expiration EXPIRATION] [--request-type REQUEST_TYPE] [--subject-dn SUBJECT_DN] [--source-container-ref SOURCE_CONTAINER_REF] [--ca-id CA_ID] [--profile PROFILE] [--request-file REQUEST_FILE] type Create a new order. Positional arguments -------------------- ``type`` the type of the order to create. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit ``--name NAME, -n NAME`` a human-friendly name. ``--algorithm ALGORITHM, -a ALGORITHM`` the algorithm to be used with the requested key (default: aes). ``--bit-length BIT_LENGTH, -b BIT_LENGTH`` the bit length of the requested secret key (default: 256). ``--mode MODE, -m MODE`` the algorithm mode to be used with the requested key (default: cbc). ``--payload-content-type PAYLOAD_CONTENT_TYPE, -t PAYLOAD_CONTENT_TYPE`` the type/format of the secret to be generated (default: application/octet-stream). ``--expiration EXPIRATION, -x EXPIRATION`` the expiration time for the secret in ISO 8601 format. ``--request-type REQUEST_TYPE`` the type of the certificate request. ``--subject-dn SUBJECT_DN`` the subject of the certificate. ``--source-container-ref SOURCE_CONTAINER_REF`` the source of the certificate when using stored-key requests. ``--ca-id CA_ID`` the identifier of the CA to use for the certificate request. ``--profile PROFILE`` the profile of certificate to use. ``--request-file REQUEST_FILE`` the file containing the CSR. .. _barbican_secret_order_delete: barbican secret order delete ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican secret order delete [-h] URI Delete an order by providing its href. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the order Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit .. _barbican_secret_order_get: barbican secret order get ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican secret order get [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--prefix PREFIX] URI Retrieve an order by providing its URI. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference order. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit .. _barbican_secret_order_list: barbican secret order list ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican secret order list [-h] [-f {csv,html,json,table,value,yaml}] [-c COLUMN] [--max-width <integer>] [--noindent] [--quote {all,minimal,none,nonnumeric}] [--limit LIMIT] [--offset OFFSET] List orders. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit ``--limit LIMIT, -l LIMIT`` specify the limit to the number of items to list per page (default: 10; maximum: 100) ``--offset OFFSET, -o OFFSET`` specify the page offset (default: 0) usage: barbican secret store [-h] [-f {html,json,shell,table,value,yaml}].. _barbican_secret_update: barbican secret update ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: barbican secret update [-h] URI payload Update a secret with no payload in Barbican. Positional arguments -------------------- ``URI`` The URI reference for the secret. ``payload`` the unencrypted secret Optional arguments ------------------ ``-h, --help`` show this help message and exit

subject: Add upgrade config playbook and backup configs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-26 21:59:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/51540b61742377e1eda8c3c5c873d4eac1a137bb', 'message': 'Add upgrade config change tools

This commit provides the first of the configuration change tools for
Liberty. This provides a script to back up the configuration directory,
the playbook to run it, the upgrade script invocation of said playbook,
and the documentation for the script and the playbook.

The included release note is intended to serve for all configuration
related work, but not all such work is included yet in order to keep the
patch size manageable for reviewers.

commit_message:
Add upgrade config playbook and backup configs

This commit provides a playbook that initially will back up the
configuration directory, as well as documentation for that playbook. In
later commits, this playbook will be extended to change the existing
configuration in place.

The included release note is intended to serve for all configuration
related work, but not all such work is included yet in order to keep the
patch size manageable for reviewers.

Change-Id: I1dcc6639ec31262bbc9a8f3cfa6099a1c8e4d8dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/64/285564/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _backup-script: backup-deploy-dir.sh -------------------- This script will copy the existing ``/etc/openstack_deploy`` directory to ``/etc/openstack_deploy.KILO``, as well as a gzipped tar file with the current date in the current user's $HOME folder (most likely ``/root/``). In addition, this file will create the ``/etc/openstack_deploy.KILO/DEPRECATED`` file, which the :ref:`config-change-playbook` playbook will use to determine whether or not to execute the command on subsequent runs. This script was used rather than the Ansible ``copy`` or ``synchronize`` modules since it was found those modules will copy the contents of ``/etc/openstack_deploy`` to ``/etc/openstack_deploy.KILO`` on subsequent runs when changes by later scripts are detected. This behavior is undesirable because the ``/etc/openstack_deploy.KILO`` directory is meant to represent the configuration prior to migration.

commit_message:
Don't ignore failures when delete nodes

Deleting nodes ignore failures and just prints the results which nodes
are deleted and which are failed.

But in case failure it doesn't propagate exception further, as result
success command execution, return code of cmd is 0.

Closes-Bug: #1552224
Change-Id: I48be1d1ddf199b75cd09f6df6bdff5fef2f24334
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/77/287177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Deleting nodes ignore failures and just prints the results which nodes are deleted and which are failed, as result node-delete always return 0 code.

commit_message:
Updated iLO driver documentation to recommend ipmitool version

While discovering the capabilities of the baremetal server using
iLO drivers, to support the capability "nic_capacity", it is
recommended to use ipmitool version >= 1.8.15

Closes-Bug: #1540842
Change-Id: I6d72a6e36672b8e164f779c5987457ff2e538958
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/47/274547/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: The capability ``nic_capacity`` can only be discovered if ipmitool version >= 1.8.15 is used on the conductor. The latest version can be downloaded from `here <http://sourceforge.net/projects/ipmitool/>`_.

commit_message:
Add CLI support for RAID configuration

This commits add the following:

* Ability to set target_raid_config for a node using
  node-set-target-raid-config.

* Display target_raid_config and raid_config in node-show.

* Display logical disk properties for a driver using
  driver-raid-logical-disk-properties.

NOTE: Client still defaults to version 1.9, so
  '--ironic-api-version 1.15' (or above) should be
  added to the CLI to use the feature as RAID can be
  triggered only with manual cleaning which uses the
  ironic-api-version 1.15.

Co-Authored-By: Nisha Agarwal <agarwalnisha1980@gmail.com>
Closes_bug: 1526400
Change-Id: Id7bb8a242838029e4cc3715d18b27fb1d5cd4dfa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/34/226234/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'raid_config': 'Current RAID configuration', 'target_raid_config': 'Target RAID configuration', 'raid_config', 'target_raid_config',

commit_message:
Support metadata update issue for v2

Now there is no way to update metadata after queue create.
That because we were trying to remove metadata but finally we
decided to keep it. As a result, we missed a way to update queue's
metadata. This patch fixes it buy supporting PATCH for queue. And
a test case is added.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1543900

commit_message:
ipxe: add --timeout parameter to kernel and initrd

In case of network issue during the download of the ramdisk or the
kernel, ipxe can freeze. The default timeout value is "unlimited" [0] [1].
If force_power_state_during_sync is False, ironic will just ignore the
node until someone do an human intervention.

By setting a timeout, we ensure ipxe will just give up. Depending on the
BIOS configuration, a new boot attempt may be done immedialey without the
hassle of a hard reboot.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1310778

[0] http://ipxe.org/cmd/kernel
[1] http://lists.ipxe.org/pipermail/ipxe-devel/2014-October/003829.html

Closes-Bug: 1550417
Change-Id: I472dfb73044df50849c9cf72de90e59151698376

commit_message:
Use keystoneauth instead of keystoneclient

This change also enables client to be authenticated via 'token'
keystone auth method, allowing to pass os_auth_token instead of
os_username and os_password.

Closes-bug: #1541411
Closes-bug: #1548907
Change-Id: I9739c95069ebf8d60f8362be154844e74334beb2

added_lines: from keystoneauth1 import loading as kaloading from keystoneauth1 import session as kasession * os_tenant_{name|id}: name or ID of a tenant (deprecated in favour of os_project_{name|id}) * os_project_{name|id}: name or ID of a project * os_user_domain_{name|id}: name or ID of a domain the user belongs to * os_project_domain_{name|id}: name or ID of a domain the project belongs to project_id = (kwargs.get('os_project_id') or kwargs.get('os_tenant_id')) project_name = (kwargs.get('os_project_name') or kwargs.get('os_tenant_name')) cli_kwargs = {} cli_kwargs['token'] = token for key in ('insecure', 'timeout', 'ca_file', 'cert_file', 'key_file'): cli_kwargs[key] = kwargs.get(key) (project_id or project_name)): auth_kwargs = { 'project_id': project_id, 'project_name': project_name, 'user_domain_id': kwargs.get('os_user_domain_id'), 'user_domain_name': kwargs.get('os_user_domain_name'), 'project_domain_id': kwargs.get('os_project_domain_id'), 'project_domain_name': kwargs.get('os_project_domain_name'), } auth_type = 'password' loader = kaloading.get_plugin_loader(auth_type) auth_plugin = loader.load_from_options(**auth_kwargs) session = kasession.Session(auth=auth_plugin, verify=(not kwargs.get('insecure'))) endpoint = ( kwargs.get('ironic_url') or session.get_endpoint( service_type=kwargs.get('service_type') or 'baremetal', endpoint_type=kwargs.get('endpoint_type') or 'publicURL' ) ) cli_kwargs['session'] = session for key in ('os_ironic_api_version', 'max_retries', 'retry_interval'):
deleted_lines: import keystoneclientdef _get_ksclient(**kwargs): """Get an endpoint and auth token from Keystone. :param kwargs: keyword args containing credentials: * username: name of user * password: user's password * auth_url: endpoint to authenticate against * insecure: allow insecure SSL (no cert verification) * tenant_{name|id}: name or ID of tenant """ client = keystoneclient.client.Client( username=kwargs.get('username'), password=kwargs.get('password'), tenant_id=kwargs.get('tenant_id'), tenant_name=kwargs.get('tenant_name'), auth_url=kwargs.get('auth_url'), insecure=kwargs.get('insecure')) # FIXME(jlvillal): Work around for Bug 1539839 as client.authenticate is # not called. client.authenticate() return client def _get_endpoint(client, **kwargs): """Get an endpoint using the provided keystone client.""" attr = None filter_value = None if kwargs.get('region_name'): attr = 'region' filter_value = kwargs.get('region_name') return client.service_catalog.url_for( service_type=kwargs.get('service_type') or 'baremetal', attr=attr, filter_value=filter_value, endpoint_type=kwargs.get('endpoint_type') or 'publicURL') * os_tenant_{name|id}: name or ID of tenant auth_ref = None (kwargs.get('os_tenant_id') or kwargs.get('os_tenant_name'))): ks_kwargs = { 'tenant_id': kwargs.get('os_tenant_id'), 'tenant_name': kwargs.get('os_tenant_name'), 'service_type': kwargs.get('os_service_type'), 'endpoint_type': kwargs.get('os_endpoint_type'), 'insecure': kwargs.get('insecure'), } _ksclient = _get_ksclient(**ks_kwargs) token = (kwargs.get('os_auth_token') if kwargs.get('os_auth_token') else _ksclient.auth_token) ks_kwargs['region_name'] = kwargs.get('os_region_name') endpoint = (kwargs.get('ironic_url') or _get_endpoint(_ksclient, **ks_kwargs)) auth_ref = _ksclient.auth_ref cli_kwargs = { 'token': token, 'auth_ref': auth_ref, } for key in ('insecure', 'timeout', 'ca_file', 'cert_file', 'key_file', 'os_ironic_api_version', 'max_retries', 'retry_interval'):

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/06/285506/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - Two new overrides rabbitmq_async_threads and rabbitmq_process_limit have been added. rabbitmq_async_threads limits the number of asynchronous threads for file and socket IO rabbitmq_process_limit limits the overall number of supported processes inside the erlang VM upgrade: - The number of erlang asynchronous threads have been increased to 128 from 32 to support higher Openstack related workload - The maximum erlang process limit has been set to 1048576 so prevent VM lockups in case the limit has been exhausted

commit_message:
Docs: Removing redundant config README

Given that this doc is not part of the install or dev
guides and that nearly all of its content is already present
in those guides, we should remove this and focus our
maintenance effort on the more widely used documentation.

Change-Id: I7d68ceef8e44da3ecc8e13729db4787eb835be82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/17/283117/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: as well as a CIDR that your containers will have IP addresses assigned from. This allows for easy scaling as new nodes and or affinity for containers is all set within this file. Please see the ``openstack_user_config.yml`` file in the provided ``/etc`` directory for more details on howIf you want to specify globally available options and do not want to place them in ``var_files`` or within the ``group_vars/all.yml`` file you can set them in a key = value pair within the ``global_overrides`` hash.The user configuration file has 12 groups defined in the ``openstack_user_config.yml`` file. The groups are: * shared-infra_hosts * repo-infra_hosts * os-infra_hosts * identity_hosts * network_hosts * compute_hosts * storage-infra_hosts * storage_hosts * log_hosts * metering-infra_hosts * metering-compute_hosts * metering-alarm_hosts Any host specified within these groups will have containers built within them automatically. Which containers are built on which hosts is controlled by mappings within ``/etc/openstack_deploy/env.d/*.yml`` files. Hosts are assigned to groups using syntax like:``infra_host1`` is the host name and ``ip`` is used to set the known IP address of the host. Even if you have the host names set within your environment using either the ``hosts`` file or a resolver you must specify the IP. If you want to use a host that is not in a predefined group and is used in some custom out of band Ansible play you can add a top level key for the host group with the host name and ip key. The syntax is the exact same as the predefined host groups.
deleted_lines: as well as a CIDR that your containers will have IP addresses assigned from. This allows for easy scaling as new nodes and or affinity for containers is all set within this file. Please see the ``openstack_user_config.yml`` file in the provided ``/etc`` directory for more details on how If you want to specify specific globally available options and do not want to place them in ``var_files`` or within the ``group_vars/all.yml`` file you can set them in a key = value pair within the ``global_overrides`` hash.The user configuration file has 4 defined groups which have mapping found within the ``openstack_environment.yml`` file. The predefined groups are: * os-infra_hosts: * shared-infra_hosts: * compute_hosts: * storage_hosts: * log_hosts: Any host specified within these groups will have containers built within them automatically. The containers that will be build are all mapped out within the openstack_environment.json file. When specifying hosts inside of any of the known groups the syntax is as follows: With this the top key is the host name and ip is used to set the known IP address of the host name. Even if you have the host names set within your environment using either the ``hosts`` file or a resolver you must specify the "ip". If you want to use a host that is not in a predefined group and is used is some custom out of band Ansible play you can add a top level key for the host type with the host name and "ip" key. The syntax is the exact same as the predefined host groups.

This file will automatically be removed if the deployer is not using the Default domain with an LDAP back end. (`Bug 1547542 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1547542>`_)

commit_message:
Add a function to check accuracy of user config

The _check_config_settings function helps users to early
identify correctness of user config settings such as the
presence of provider networks in the proper spot
if needed and validity of ip_from_q inside
provider_networks.

Change-Id: I6b09a6b8ade309ac845c419f39db06bde72097f7
Closes-Bug: 1545205
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/67/282067/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _ensure_config_integrity(cidr_networks, config, container_skel): """ check integrity of config :param cidr_networks: ``dict`` cidr_networks from config :param config: ``dict`` User defined information :param container_skel: ``dict`` container skeleton for all known containers """ # search for any container that dosen't have is_metal flag set to true is_provider_networks_valid = False for key, value in container_skel.iteritems(): properties = value.get('properties') is_metal = properties.get('is_metal', False) if not is_metal: is_provider_networks_valid = True break if is_provider_networks_valid: if ('global_overrides' not in config): raise SystemExit( "global_overrides can't be find in user config" ) elif ('provider_networks' not in config['global_overrides']): raise SystemExit( "provider networks can't be find under " "global_overrides in user config" ) else: # make sure that provider networks's ip_from_q is valid overrides = config['global_overrides'] pns = overrides.get('provider_networks', list()) for pn in pns: p_net = pn.get('network') if not p_net: continue q_name = p_net.get('ip_from_q') if q_name and q_name not in cidr_networks: raise SystemExit( "can't find " + q_name + " in cidr_networks" ) # make sure user_defined config is self contained _ensure_config_integrity( cidr_networks, user_defined_config, environment.get('container_skel') )

commit_message:
Huawei: Consider bandwidth when selecting port

Currently we count the weight of each FC port when
selecting port for zoning, but if all the weights
are equal, for example, at the very beginning when
all ports' weight are zero, we should select the
ports which have the bigger bandwidth.

Closes-Bug: #1548220
Change-Id: I59b3f0bb9adb1038f54b2f4a3c1dfa8bdc520ae9

commit_message:
During functional tests, 404 response to a DELETE is successful

Previously, we would only consider 204 responses successful, which would
cause some spurious gate failures, such as

http://logs.openstack.org/66/287666/3/check/gate-swift-dsvm-functional/c6d2673/console.html#_2016-03-03_13_41_07_846

Change-Id: Ic8c300647924352a297a2781b50064f7657038b4

commit_message:
Wait for udev to settle before listing the block devices

This patch is making the list_all_block_devices() method to wait for
udev to settle it's event queue prior to listing the devices.

Sometimes the ironic-python-agent service may start before all devices
were detected and end up erroring out because it couldn't find a
suitable disk for deployment.

Closes-Bug: #1551300
Change-Id: I1ae2062a711115a1ea14b79ae9ace7ddd2fff9d5

commit_message:
Updating docs with support for DL class servers

This patch updates the documentation with new supported Server Hardware class
(DL360 Gen9) and recommendations about installing python-oneviewclient to
enable the support.

This patch also corrects a misleading minimum version of python-oneviewclient on
L57.

Change-Id: I97460bfbd5467496ba3b21fbca55249b31d88d5c

commit_message:
Fixed a bug in ScaleIO volume not found code.

The code is 79 and not 78.

commit_message:
Fix location update

After commit Ieb03aaba887492819f9c58aa67f7acfcea81720e, the command
location-update is totally broken now. This patch fixes the issue
and a test case is added. Besides, with this change, location
add/remove/update can't be executed if the show_multiple_locations
is False.

APIImpact
DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1537626

Change-Id: I7284dee828bc8ca00747bc7668b37fa7176afc85
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/86/280786/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pdb pdb.set_trace() # NOTE(flwang): When only one location passed in and the URL of the # location is existing, that means user would like to update the # metadata. if len(value) == 1: for loc in image.locations: if value[0]['url'] == loc['url']: loc['metadata'] = value[0]['metadata'] value = image.locations break else: msg = _("Failed to update location's metadata, the URL of" " location is not existing in current image's" " locations.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg) else: msg = _("Cannot replace locations from a non-empty " "list to a non-empty list.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)
deleted_lines: msg = _("Cannot replace locations from a non-empty " "list to a non-empty list.") raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

commit_message:
Material Design: New LI Tweaks

Some things on the new LI needed tweaking for material design:

 * Help Icon Strangeness -- Snazz added
 * Material Icon Alignment -- Removed Custom Size
 * Required Icon Size Strangeness - Specificity Required

Change-Id: I09620f25192352ab47dd329e8a594a9fd091a6a3
partial-bug: 1538491

but the instance has not yet been scheduled to a cell, it should be

commit_message:
Make InstanceMappings.cell_id nullable

In order to indicate that an instance boot request has been received,
but the instance has not yet been scheduled to a cell, it should be
mapped to a null cell_id. This will mean that an instance list/show will
need to fetch the instance details from the BuildRequest object rather
than looking for the instance in a cell database. A migration is added
and the InstanceMapping object is modified to make this possible.

Partially-implements: bp cells-scheduling-interaction

Change-Id: Iee768512314f11a13e2a85a1e7d5442864ddbc4b

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from sqlalchemy import MetaData from sqlalchemy import Table def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine instance_mapping = Table('instance_mappings', meta, autoload=True) instance_mapping.c.cell_id.alter(nullable=True)

commit_message:
Create BuildRequest object during boot process

The BuildRequest object represents a boot request before an instance has
been created and written to the database. It will be required to respond
to API requests to list/show an instance in cellsv2 where the instance
is not written to the database immediately. An upcoming change will
modify the boot process to defer instance creation until after
scheduling has picked a cell/host and having this BuildRequest object
persisted is a prerequisite for that work. The BuildRequest object
lifetime ends as soon as the instance has been written to a database and
a mapping is in place for it. Until instance creation moves the
BuildRequest object is destroyed rather quickly.

Note there is a small optimization added here such that when creating
instances in the API, only populate the SecurityGroupList once rather
than each pass in the for loop (if building multiple instances).

Change-Id: I080fa53d13f7301f6f7f2977a8e3cb287a46c02c
Partially-implements: bp cells-scheduling-interaction
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/278125/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Store the BuildRequest that will help populate an instance # object for a list/show request info_cache = objects.InstanceInfoCache() info_cache.instance_uuid = instance_uuid info_cache.network_info = network_model.NetworkInfo() sec_groups = self.security_group_api.populate_security_groups( security_groups) build_request = objects.BuildRequest.from_components(context, instance_uuid=instance_uuid, request_spec=req_spec, display_name=base_options['display_name'], metadata=base_options['metadata'], progress=0, vm_state=vm_states.BUILDING, task_state=task_states.SCHEDULING, access_ip_v4=base_options['access_ip_v4'], access_ip_v6=base_options['access_ip_v6'], info_cache=info_cache, security_groups=sec_groups, config_drive=base_options['config_drive'], key_name=base_options['key_name'], locked_by=None) build_request.create() # TODO(alaski): Cast to conductor here which will call the # scheduler and defer instance creation until the scheduler # has picked a cell/host. # The BuildRequest needs to be stored until the instance is in # an instance table. At that point it will never be used again # and should be deleted. As instance creation is pushed back, # as noted above, this will move with it. build_request.destroy()

commit_message:
Fix role based indexing for designate

Fixes an issue missed during the role-based index separation work
with designate because it has some custom code during Domain (zone)
creation to index initial recordsets that aren't mentioned specifically
in their own notifications.

This fixes some issues with deleting child documents. There are still
some outstanding problems around handling role separation with
parent/child docs that will be dealt with in a separate patch.

Change-Id: I31e7b795b037ce7a31ce06135aa40a7ea6e4bb64
Closes-Bug: #1543245
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/08/280908/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_notification_handler(self): """Override because the zone handler needs a handle to recordset indexer (for initial recordset indexing). """ return self.NotificationHandlerCls( self.index_helper, self.options, recordset_helper=self.child_plugins[0].index_helper)

commit_message:
No longer defining OS_TENANT_NAME in openrc

Change Ifabb4a2aec070c00349e794364a71394feea99f1 in python-cinderclient
1.4.0 means the presence of OS_TENANT_NAME is no longer
required

Change-Id: I8210f8a48f482f19ae3eb70c5ae0bf649a9b856a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_openrc refs/changes/09/287309/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Reconfigure for Heat

Add reconfiguration for heat-api, heat-engine, heat-api-cfn.

Change-Id: I60d538d08eaf1db38876cccbb0db530b52d302b8
Partially-Implements: blueprint kolla-reconfig

added_lines: --- - name: Ensuring the containers up kolla_docker: name: "{{ item.name }}" action: "get_container_state" register: container_state failed_when: container_state.Running == false when: inventory_hostname in groups[item.group] with_items: - { name: heat_api, group: heat-api } - { name: heat_api_cfn, group: heat-api-cfn } - { name: heat_engine, group: heat-engine } - include: config.yml - name: Check the configs command: docker exec {{ item.name }} /usr/local/bin/kolla_set_configs --check changed_when: false failed_when: false register: check_results when: inventory_hostname in groups[item.group] with_items: - { name: heat_api, group: heat-api } - { name: heat_api_cfn, group: heat-api-cfn } - { name: heat_engine, group: heat-engine } # NOTE(jeffrey4l): when config_strategy == 'COPY_ALWAYS' # and container env['KOLLA_CONFIG_STRATEGY'] == 'COPY_ONCE', # just remove the container and start again - name: Containers config strategy kolla_docker: name: "{{ item.name }}" action: "get_container_env" register: container_envs when: inventory_hostname in groups[item.group] with_items: - { name: heat_api, group: heat-api } - { name: heat_api_cfn, group: heat-api-cfn } - { name: heat_engine, group: heat-engine } - name: Remove the containers kolla_docker: name: "{{ item[0]['name'] }}" action: "remove_container" register: remove_containers when: - config_strategy == "COPY_ONCE" or item[1]['KOLLA_CONFIG_STRATEGY'] == 'COPY_ONCE' - item[2]['rc'] == 1 - inventory_hostname in groups[item[0]['group']] with_together: - [{ name: heat_api, group: heat-api }, { name: heat_api_cfn, group: heat-api-cfn }, { name: heat_engine, group: heat-engine }] - container_envs.results - check_results.results - include: start.yml when: remove_containers.changed - name: Restart containers kolla_docker: name: "{{ item[0]['name'] }}" action: "restart_container" when: - commit_message:
Fixes keystone library incompatibility with the Keystone v3 client

When configuring federated identity mapping for Keystone using example here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible/install-guide/configure-federation-mapping.html

Task [os_keystone | Ensure Group/Project/Role mapping exists]
fails with:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/484433/

Change-Id: I522b6a3f5609db0f8a20157625eebd28d9e2601c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins refs/changes/86/274686/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_group_roles(self, name, group, project): project=project name=role_name, group=group, project=project project=project
deleted_lines: def _get_group_roles(self, name, group, project, domain): project=project, domain=domain name=role_name, group=group, project=project, domain=domain project=project, domain=domain

subject: Implmement NVRAM store and manager
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-16 16:40:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/d81c82d5e3d3222c53775bab4ff3da96a8eb00cc', 'message': "WIP: Implmement NVRAM store and manager

PowerVM has NVRAM that is associated with each VM on the system.
The NVRAM holds information about the VM such as which device
is the boot device. PowerVM produces an event when the NVRAM for
a VM is changed.

The NVRAM should be set on the VM during operations like cold
migration, resize to a different host and evacuation when the
VM is newly created on the destination host from an existing VM
on the source host.

This change set introduces the concept of an NVRAM store and
an NVRAM manager. The compute driver listens for the PowerVM
NVRAM change events and stores the NVRAM in the configured store.

A Swift store for the NVRAM is implemented.

Future change sets will utilize the NVRAM from the store on VM
operations and manage it's life cycle.

WIP: Needs more UT written.

Change-Id: I59be9946794f53fdcae5515cc818d4fe967986d0

commit_message:
Implmement NVRAM store and manager

PowerVM has NVRAM that is associated with each VM on the system.
The NVRAM holds information about the VM such as which device
is the boot device. PowerVM produces an event when the NVRAM for
a VM is changed.

The NVRAM should be set on the VM during operations like cold
migration, resize to a different host and evacuation when the
VM is newly created on the destination host from an existing VM
on the source host.

This change set introduces the concept of an NVRAM store and
an NVRAM manager. The compute driver listens for the PowerVM
NVRAM change events and stores the NVRAM in the configured store.

A Swift store for the NVRAM is implemented.

Future change sets will utilize the NVRAM from the store on VM
operations and manage its life cycle. This change set does
include storing the NVRAM during migrate/resize and was included
to facilitate live testing.

Change-Id: I59be9946794f53fdcae5515cc818d4fe967986d0

commit_message:
Fix Swift log directory ownership

This PR sets the ownership for the swift log directories to the syslog
user instead of the swift user. Since swift uses syslog, no logs were
being created/logged to before this change.

Change-Id: I44768d4cd04108a7163169dfec2f0de774a2cf83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_swift refs/changes/37/287337/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: chown -h {{ swift_syslog_user_name }}:{{ swift_syslog_group_name }} "/var/log/swift" chown -R {{ swift_syslog_user_name }}:{{ swift_syslog_group_name }} "$(readlink /var/log/swift)"
deleted_lines: chown -h {{ swift_system_user_name }}:{{ swift_system_group_name }} "/var/log/swift" chown -R {{ swift_system_user_name }}:{{ swift_system_group_name }} "$(readlink /var/log/swift)"

subject: Add testing for dynamic_inventory.py
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-05 21:26:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/6cc78f7afa3d12a210cf77c98fd1361279d56f42', 'message': "Add testing for dynamic_inventory.py

This change introduces a testing framework for the dynamic_inventory.py
script, which will be helpful in debugging any changes made to the
script. Current testing is indirect, relying on the other, very high
level gate tests, which may take longer to identify inventory generation
issues.

Currently, it does not do actual unit testing, instead opting to start
by testing from 'outside', calling the script through a submodule. In
time, this should be replaced, but as a start it's easier to implement
without making many changes.

The 'test/' directory has the necessary pieces symlinked in; namely,
env.d, openstack_environment.yml, and a saml openstack_user-config.yml
(based on the AIO one already used in the gates).

A new tox environment, 'inventory' was added rather than creating a new
'gate-check-inventory.sh' file. This should fit the general
openstack-infra testing framework better.

For the first test, I decided to add a loop that runs 100 times because
of the nature of the script. Since the dynamic_inventory script does not
assign IP addresses sequentially, the loop helps exercise a larger
sample than just one run per test. On my local machine, this took
approximately 2 seconds. Running it 1,000 times took about 30 seconds.
Thus, the time spent right now is minimal in comparison to the rest of
the gate jobs.

As it stands, the test suite is by no means complete, but serves as a
starting point.

Change-Id: I7410360ecec919639a299f72f2f3cc818bce8e33
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-05 21:29:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/87f44bf26778e282e35c916db24b87d957bdc04a', 'message': "Add testing for dynamic_inventory.py

namely, env.d, openstack_environment.yml, and a sample
openstack_user-config.yml (based on the AIO one already used in the gates).

A new tox environment, 'inventory' was added rather than creating a new
'gate-check-inventory.sh' file. This should fit the general
openstack-infra testing framework better.

For the first test, I decided to add a loop that runs 100 times because
of the nature of the script. Since the dynamic_inventory script does not
assign IP addresses sequentially, the loop helps exercise a larger
sample than just one run per test. On my local machine, this took
approximately 2 seconds. Running it 1,000 times took about 30 seconds.
Thus, the time spent right now is minimal in comparison to the rest of
the gate jobs.

As it stands, the test suite is by no means complete, but serves as a
starting point.

Change-Id: I7410360ecec919639a299f72f2f3cc818bce8e33
Implements: blueprint dynamic-inventory-lib

commit_message:
Add testing for dynamic_inventory.py

This change introduces a testing framework for the dynamic_inventory.py
script, which will be helpful in debugging any changes made to the
script. Current testing is indirect, relying on the other, very high
level gate tests, which may take longer to identify inventory generation
issues.

Currently, it does not do actual unit testing, instead opting to start
by testing from 'outside', calling the script through a subprocess. In
time, this should be replaced, but as a start it's easier to implement
without making many changes.

The 'tests/inventory' directory has the necessary pieces symlinked in;
namely, env.d, openstack_environment.yml, and a sample
openstack_user-config.yml (based on the AIO one already used in the gates).

A new tox environment, 'inventory' was added rather than creating a new
'gate-check-inventory.sh' file. This should fit the general
openstack-infra testing framework better.

For the first test, I decided to add a loop that runs 100 times because
of the nature of the script. Since the dynamic_inventory script does not
assign IP addresses sequentially, the loop helps exercise a larger
sample than just one run per test. On my local machine, this took
approximately 2 seconds. Running it 1,000 times took about 30 seconds.
Thus, the time spent right now is minimal in comparison to the rest of
the gate jobs.

As it stands, the test suite is by no means complete, but serves as a
starting point.

Change-Id: I7410360ecec919639a299f72f2f3cc818bce8e33

commit_message:
Fix swift log perms

The change adjusts the permissions on the siwft logging directory
to ensure syslog is always able to read and write logs to the
proper location.

Re-Implementation-Of: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/275311/1

Change-Id: Ic2dc66167db4158b8ea0dcb6157ddb1d0d55df66
Closes-Bug: #1539207
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_swift refs/changes/26/287926/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: chown -h syslog:syslog "/var/log/swift" chown -R syslog:syslog "$(readlink /var/log/swift)"
deleted_lines: chown -h {{ swift_system_user_name }}:{{ swift_system_group_name }} "/var/log/swift" chown -R {{ swift_system_user_name }}:{{ swift_system_group_name }} "$(readlink /var/log/swift)"

commit_message:
Correct filename of clouds.yml to clouds.yaml

According to the python-openstackclient doc, the correct
filename is clouds.yaml. See
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/configuration.html
for details.

Change-Id: If7dea05f6787b4dc94369d5f1a6db8dd20741697

commit_message:
Cannot rebuild a instance booted from volume

allow user to detach a root device volume.
and modify the get_next_device_name method to
return root_device_name to enable user to
attach a volume as root device.

Closes-Bug: #1474253
Change-Id: I9dc8cd8fde5c587ba5e6a0187fa19620aeb0920b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/58/201458/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance['root_device_name'], device)

subject: Bug fix: volume booted instance rebuild doesn't change operating system in root device
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 01:32:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6a47221d709d9162a69c626fe8758897141b0d26', 'message': "Fix bug: volume booted instance rebuild doesn't change operating system in root device

Before the fix, when rebuilding instances booted from volume, the root device isn't changed:
it's only detached before hypervisor destroys the instance and get attached back after
hypervisor spawns the instance. As a result the operating system isn't changed.

The fix works in the ordering:
1. After the root device is detached, it calls cinder api to delete the volume
2. Change attributes of the root bdm entry: set volume_id/connection_info to None,
change image_id to the new image_id.

So when attaching back, a new volume will be created as volume_id is None for the bdm
and a new image will be downloaded to the volume.

For non-root device, it wont delete/recreate it.

Change-Id: I4da8edf33c910d658fa91e4f631290f5a9b98745
Closes-Bug: #1470702

commit_message:
Bug fix: volume booted instance rebuild doesn't change operating system in root device

Before the fix, when rebuilding instances booted from volume, the root device isn't changed:
it's only detached before hypervisor destroys the instance and get attached back after
hypervisor spawns the instance. As a result the operating system isn't changed.

The fix works in the way:
1. After the root device is detached, it calls cinder api to delete the volume
2. Change attributes of the root bdm entry: set volume_id/connection_info to None,
change image_id to the new image_id.

So when attaching back, a new volume will be created as volume_id is None for the bdm
and a new image will be downloaded to the volume.

For non-root device, it wont delete/recreate it.

Change-Id: I4da8edf33c910d658fa91e4f631290f5a9b98745
Closes-Bug: #1470702
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/223887/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not image_meta or 'id' not in image_meta: raise exception.InvalidImageMeta(image_meta=image_meta) if recreate: detach_block_devices(context, bdms, image_meta['id']) detach_block_devices(context, bdms, image_meta['id']) def detach_block_devices(context, bdms, image_id): if bdm.is_root: self.volume_api.delete(context, bdm.volume_id) bdm.volume_id = None bdm.connection_info = None bdm.image_id = image_id bdm.save()

commit_message:
Fix incorrect unit test for router

Command "router show" will display router's "tenant_id" as
"project_id". But in the unit test, it checks "tenant_id",
which is incorrect.

This patch fix this problem, and add a _get_columns() helper
function to simplify the code.

Change-Id: I0087ef7dfd0130b6c47222495848c4f2b9804b1b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/85/287785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'project_id', _router.project_id,

subject: Add BuildRequest object
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-09 22:24:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7b655737830dcd36e01a62284f58dcfc173f0ea5', 'message': 'Add BuildRequest object

The BuildRequest object represents a boot request before an instance has
been created and written to the database. It will be required to respond
to API requests to list/show an instance in cellsv2 where the instance
is not written to the database immediately. An upcoming change will
modify the boot process to defer instance creation until after
scheduling has picked a cell/host and having this BuildRequest object is
a prerequisite for that work.

Change-Id: Ie9307388c2e068229177bcc4690cb834028c1481
Partially-implements: bp cells-scheduling-interaction

to API requests to list/show an instance in cellsv2 where the instance
is not written to the database immediately. An upcoming change will
modify the boot process to defer instance creation until after
scheduling has picked a cell/host and having this BuildRequest object is
a prerequisite for that work.

Change-Id: Ie9307388c2e068229177bcc4690cb834028c1481
Partially-implements: bp cells-scheduling-interaction
'}]
commit_message:
Add BuildRequest object

The BuildRequest object represents a boot request before an instance has
been created and written to the database. It will be required to respond
to API requests to list/show an instance in cellsv2 where the instance
is not written to the database immediately. An upcoming change will
modify the boot process to defer instance creation until after
scheduling has picked a cell/host and having this BuildRequest object is
a prerequisite for that work.

Change-Id: Ie9307388c2e068229177bcc4690cb834028c1481
Partially-implements: bp cells-scheduling-interaction

commit_message:
Neutron plugin

Adds neutron network and port support. Routers and subnets to come.

Note that neutron resources don't include any date information.
updated_at is set from the notification timestamp.

Change-Id: I5a4a4db4daffec6015485a0e4847ec7b425303bc
Implements-blueprint: neutron-plugin

subject: Remove pre-1.0 glance auth error handling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-03 19:34:19.000000000', 'files': ['searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/openstack_clients.py', 'searchlight/tests/unit/test_glance_image_plugin.py', 'searchlight/elasticsearch/plugins/glance/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/searchlight/commit/d1125ae6138724b06ed252fa92d133532f7a61e6', 'message': "Remove pre-1.0 glance auth error handling

Prior to glance 1.0 (which didn't use keystone sessions) we implemented
custom authorization error retry code for glance. glanceclient 2.0.0
was no longer compatible with some of the tests for that code, and the
minimum requirement for glanceclient in mitaka is now 1.2.0. As a
result, this patch switches glance to using the same session-based auth
all the other clients do. This has been tested for gc 1.2 and 2.0.

Change-Id: Ida5b3c3bff5cc6e933a4c6dc0b7f5f429ddf4554
Closes-Bug: #1552875

commit_message:
Remove pre-1.0 glance auth error handling

Prior to glance 1.0 (which didn't use keystone sessions) we implemented
custom authorization error retry code for glance. glanceclient 2.0.0
was no longer compatible with some of the tests for that code, and the
minimum requirement for glanceclient in mitaka is now 1.2.0. As a
result, this patch switches glance to using the same session-based auth
all the other clients do. This has been tested for gc 1.2 and 2.0.

Change-Id: Ida5b3c3bff5cc6e933a4c6dc0b7f5f429ddf4554
Closes-Bug: #1552875

commit_message:
Add missing content-length header

This patch adds missing content-length header
param into swift_upload_object() method.
Without it object upload handling could be failed
with "411 Length Required" error if Ceph is used
as an object storage.

Change-Id: Id0813806abb36a6f015efd13ec987492a3701476
Closes-Bug: #1352256
(cherry picked from commit 8201d65cf983f9c995dd653953ad1719f6df8459)

subject: Set the bridge MTU dynamically
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-03 16:23:15.000000000', 'files': ['devstack-vm-gate.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/2a65d2ba8671a5e910cc69833d6e7a81d4a55185', 'message': "Set the bridge MTU dynamically

Don't always assume our MTU will always be 1500 when calculating the
MTUs of overlays running inside our test nodes. Instead determine our
smallest interface MTU, subtract 50 from that for vxlan overhead (and
GRE too since GRE has less overhead than vxlan), and use this new number
on the overlay networks.

Change-Id: If5facee99f03c0ec4773241f872477b922a6674e
"}]
commit_message:
Set the bridge MTU dynamically

Don't always assume our MTU will always be 1500 when calculating the
MTUs of overlays running inside our test nodes. Instead determine our
smallest interface MTU, subtract 50 from that for vxlan overhead (and
GRE too since GRE has less overhead than vxlan), and use this new number
on the overlay networks.

Change-Id: If5facee99f03c0ec4773241f872477b922a6674e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/58/287958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Get the smallest local MTU LOCAL_MTU=$(ip link show | sed -ne 's/.*mtu \([0-9]\+\).*/\1/p' | sort -n | head -1) # 50 bytes is overhead for vxlan (which is greater than GRE # allowing us to use either overlay option with this MTU. EXTERNAL_BRIDGE_MTU=$((LOCAL_MTU - 50))

commit_message:
Add TLS protection on external API endpoints

TLS can be used to encrypt and authenticate the connection with
OpenStack endpoints.  This patch provides the necessary
parameters and changes the resulting service configurations to
enable TLS for the Kolla deployed OpenStack cloud.

The new input parameters are:

kolla_enable_tls_external: "yes" or "no" (default is "no")
kolla_external_fqdn_cert: "/etc/kolla/certificates/haproxy.pem"
kolla_external_fqdn_cacert: "/etc/kolla/certificates/haproxy-ca.crt"

Implements: blueprint kolla-ssl

Change-Id: I48ef8a781c3035d58817f9bf6f36d59a488bab41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/88/286988/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Copying over haproxy.pem when: kolla_enable_tls_external | bool copy: src: "{{ kolla_external_fqdn_cert }}" dest: "{{ node_config_directory }}/haproxy/{{ item }}" with_items: - "haproxy.pem"

commit_message:
[cli-ref] Update python-senlinclient to 0.4.0

Change-Id: I2ebd218ab4f737d52e82d4acd88de3c73fdab040
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/72/287972/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This chapter documents :command:`senlin` version ``0.4.0``. usage: senlin action-list [-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-F]``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) [-c <DESIRED-CAPACITY>] [-t <TIMEOUT>] [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] usage: senlin cluster-list [-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-g] [-F]``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) usage: senlin cluster-policy-attach -p <POLICY> [-e] <NAME or ID> [-o <SORT_STRING>] [-F]``-o <SORT_STRING>, --sort <SORT_STRING>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) usage: senlin cluster-policy-update -p <POLICY> [-e <BOOLEAN>] <NAME or ID> usage: senlin cluster-update [-p <PROFILE>] [-t <TIMEOUT>] [-m <ID>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-g] [-F]``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) usage: senlin policy-create -s <SPEC_FILE> <NAME> usage: senlin policy-list [-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>, --filters <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>`` Filter parameters to apply on returned policies. This can be specified multiple times, or once with parameters separated by a semicolon. ``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) ``-g, --global-project`` Indicate that the list should include policies from all projects. This option is subject to access policy checking. Default is False. usage: senlin policy-update [-n <NAME>] <POLICY> usage: senlin profile-create -s <SPEC FILE> [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] usage: senlin profile-list [-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>, --filters <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>`` Filter parameters to apply on returned profiles. This can be specified multiple times, or once with parameters separated by a semicolon. ``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc) ``-g, --global-project`` Indicate that the list should include profiles from all projects. This option is subject to access policy checking. Default is False. usage: senlin profile-update [-n <NAME>] [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] usage: senlin receiver-create [-t <TYPE>] -c <CLUSTER> -a <ACTION> [-m <ID>] [-o <KEY:DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-o <KEY:DIR>, --sort <KEY:DIR>`` Sorting option which is a string containing a list of keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally appened by a sort direction (:asc or :desc)

[-c <DESIRED-CAPACITY>] [-o <PARENT_ID>] [-t <TIMEOUT>] [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>]``-o <PARENT_ID>, --parent <PARENT_ID>`` ID of the parent cluster, if exists. usage: senlin cluster-list [-n] [-f <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>] [-k <KEYS>] [-s <DIR>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-g] [-F]``-n, --show-nested`` Include nested clusters if any. ``-k <KEYS>, --sort-keys <KEYS>`` Name of keys used for sorting the returned clusters. ``-s <DIR>, --sort-dir <DIR>`` Direction for sorting, where DIR can be "asc" or "desc". usage: senlin cluster-policy-attach -p <POLICY> [-r <PRIORITY>] [-l <LEVEL>] [-c <SECONDS>] [-e] <NAME or ID>``-r <PRIORITY>, --priority <PRIORITY>`` An integer specifying the relative priority among all policies attached to a cluster. The lower the value, the higher the priority. Default is 50. ``-l <LEVEL>, --enforcement-level <LEVEL>`` An integer between 0 and 100 representing the enforcement level. Default to enforcement level of policy. ``-c <SECONDS>, --cooldown <SECONDS>`` An integer indicating the cooldown seconds once the policy is effected. Default to cooldown of policy. .. _senlin_cluster-policy-disable: senlin cluster-policy-disable ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: senlin cluster-policy-disable -p <POLICY> <NAME or ID> Disable a policy on a cluster. Positional arguments -------------------- ``<NAME or ID>`` Name or ID of cluster to operate on. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-p <POLICY>, --policy <POLICY>`` ID or name of policy to be disabled. .. _senlin_cluster-policy-enable: senlin cluster-policy-enable ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: senlin cluster-policy-enable -p <POLICY> <NAME or ID> Enable a policy on a cluster. Positional arguments -------------------- ``<NAME or ID>`` Name or ID of cluster to operate on. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-p <POLICY>, --policy <POLICY>`` ID or name of policy to be enabled. [-k <KEYS>] [-s <DIR>] [-F]``-k <KEYS>, --sort-keys <KEYS>`` Name of keys used for sorting the returned policies. ``-s <DIR>, --sort-dir <DIR>`` Direction for sorting, where DIR can be "asc" or "desc". usage: senlin cluster-policy-update -p <POLICY> [-r <PRIORITY>] [-l <LEVEL>] [-c <COOLDOWN>] [-e <BOOLEAN>] <NAME or ID>``-r <PRIORITY>, --priority <PRIORITY>`` An integer specifying the relative priority among all policies attached to a cluster. The lower the value, the higher the priority. Default is 50. ``-l <LEVEL>, --enforcement-level <LEVEL>`` New enforcement level. ``-c <COOLDOWN>, --cooldown <COOLDOWN>`` Cooldown interval in seconds. usage: senlin cluster-update [-p <PROFILE>] [-t <TIMEOUT>] [-r <PARENT>]``-r <PARENT>, --parent <PARENT>`` ID of parent cluster for the cluster. [-m <ID>] [-k <KEYS>] [-s <DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-k <KEYS>, --sort-keys <KEYS>`` Name of keys used for sorting the returned events. ``-s <DIR>, --sort-dir <DIR>`` Direction for sorting, where DIR can be "asc" or "desc"... _senlin_node-join: senlin node-join ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: senlin node-join -c CLUSTER <NODE> Make node join the specified cluster. Positional arguments -------------------- ``<NODE>`` Name or ID of node to operate on. Optional arguments ------------------ ``-c CLUSTER, --cluster CLUSTER`` ID or name of cluster for node to join. .. _senlin_node-leave: senlin node-leave ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ .. code-block:: console usage: senlin node-leave <NODE> Make node leave its current cluster. Positional arguments -------------------- ``<NODE>`` Name or ID of node to operate on. [-k <KEYS>] [-s <DIR>] [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-g] [-F]``-k <KEYS>, --sort-keys <KEYS>`` Name of keys used for sorting the returned nodes. ``-s <DIR>, --sort-dir <DIR>`` Direction for sorting, where DIR can be "asc" or "desc". usage: senlin policy-create -s <SPEC_FILE> [-c <SECONDS>] [-l <LEVEL>] <NAME>``-c <SECONDS>, --cooldown <SECONDS>`` An integer indicating the cooldown seconds once the policy is effected. Default to 0. ``-l <LEVEL>, --enforcement-level <LEVEL>`` An integer between 0 and 100 representing the enforcement level. Default to 0. usage: senlin policy-list [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-F] usage: senlin policy-update [-c <SECONDS>] [-l <LEVEL>] [-n <NAME>] <POLICY>``-c <SECONDS>, --cooldown <SECONDS>`` An integer indicating the cooldown seconds once the policy is effected. Default to 0. ``-l <LEVEL>, --enforcement-level <LEVEL>`` An integer between 0 and 100 representing the enforcement level. Default to 0. usage: senlin profile-create -s <SPEC FILE> [-p <PERMISSION>] [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>]``-p <PERMISSION>, --permission <PERMISSION>`` A string format permission for this profile. usage: senlin profile-list [-l <LIMIT>] [-m <ID>] [-F] usage: senlin profile-update [-n <NAME>] [-p <PERMISSION>] [-M <KEY1=VALUE1;KEY2=VALUE2...>]``-p <PERMISSION>, --permission <PERMISSION>`` A string format permission for this profile. usage: senlin receiver-create [-t <TYPE>] [-c <CLUSTER>] -a <ACTION> [-m <ID>] [-k <KEYS>] [-s <DIR>] [-g] [-F]``-k <KEYS>, --sort-keys <KEYS>`` Name of keys used for sorting the returned receivers. ``-s <DIR>, --sort-dir <DIR>`` Direction for sorting, where DIR can be "asc" or "desc".

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/i18n refs/changes/50/287350/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Using docs.openstack.org ------------------------ Translated documents are available at the OpenStack Documentation site. It is updated daily. Most contents are linked from either of: * http://docs.openstack.org/<lang> contains released documents. Follow "More Releases and Languages" in http://docs.openstack.org/. * http://docs.openstack.org/draft/draft-index.html contains draft (unreleased) documents. TBD: How to enable translated document generation for your language and add links to the above index pages. At the moment, ask it in the i18n mailing list.Translation check site ---------------------- The infra and i18n teams are preparing the translation check site to check dashboard translations. It is under preparation. Running DevStack ---------------- Another convenient way is to check dashboard translations is to run DevStack in your local environment. To run DevStack, you need to prepare ``local.conf`` file, but no worries. Several ``local.conf`` files are shared, for example [#]_. From my experience, you need a machine with two or four CPU core, 8 GB memory and 20 GB disk to run DevStack comfortablely. .. code-block:: console $ git clone http://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack.git $ cd devstack <prepare local.conf> $ ./stack.sh <wait and wait... it takes 20 or 30 minutes> Translations are being imported into a project repository daily, so in most cases you do not need to pull translations from Zanata manually. .. [#] https://gist.github.com/amotoki/b5ca4affd768177ed911

lbaas: RDO does not define service_provider in neutron-dist.conf anymore

neutron-dist.conf file:

https://github.com/openstack-packages/neutron/blob/rpm-master/neutron-dist.conf

commit_message:
Add missed configuration in generated nova.conf.sample.

The nova.conf.sample configuration file generated by nova
is not completed. For example, power_state_check_timeframe
is not found under [hyperv] section.

This change will add the missed part.

Change-Id: I3c0aa707928787005fef051238d380071dd24332
Closes-Bug: #1542232

which causing jenkins error, so it is corrected

commit_message:
EMC ScaleIO - fix bug in extend volume

Our storage system works in 8GB granularity.
If User extends volume from X to Y while X==Y(mod 8)
it is redundant and fails the REST call.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1539099

commit_message:
Fix unittests after new releases of libraries

ironic-lib and galnceclient releases caused some of unittests to fail,
this change fixes them.

Two unittests in the test_glance_service.py module was depending on
getting an instance of the real glanceclient and it was failing due a
new glanceclient release. This patch is fixing the problem by mocking
the client instanciation.

In case of ironic-lib, new argument was added to make_partitions
function, and the mocks need to be changed.

Closes-bug: #1552839
Closes-Bug: #1552834
Co-Authored-By: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ic9dc3f1016667c6d7ec5ee324d5fff48af82c581

revisions:

Some test require to register options with oslo.Config,
but now some of them use global cfg.CONF for it.
This can cause the DuplicateOptError if two tests tried to
register the same option with different values of config.
We should use the oslo_config fixture [1]
in functional tests to avoid it.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.config/tree/oslo_config/fixture.py

Closes-bug: #1505715
Change-Id: I5c2340c0af054dfa78788cbc61dfb1fd9feea535
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid DuplicateOptError in functional tests

Some test require to register options with oslo.Config,
but now some of them use global cfg.CONF for it.
This can cause the DuplicateOptError if two tests tried to
register the same option with different values of config.
We should use the oslo_config fixture [1]
in functional tests to avoid it.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/oslo.config/tree/oslo_config/fixture.py

Closes-bug: #1505715
Change-Id: I5c2340c0af054dfa78788cbc61dfb1fd9feea535
